name: Video Interaction Guidance (VIG)
summary: Video Interaction Guidance is a therapeutic intervention that uses video feedback to help parents, caregivers, or professionals reflect on and improve communication and relationships.
description: Video Interaction Guidance (VIG) is a strengths-based, evidence-informed therapeutic approach that involves recording short video clips of everyday interactions between a parent (or caregiver) and child. A trained VIG practitioner then reviews the clips with the parent, focusing on moments of attuned interaction, positive communication, and shared understanding. By highlighting successful interactions, parents become more aware of their own strengths and develop confidence in their ability to connect with and support their child. VIG is widely used in child development, education, and family support contexts, and it has applications in social work, healthcare, and therapy. It emphasizes empowerment, self-reflection, and relationship-building rather than problem-focused approaches.

metadata.equipment_required: Video recording device, playback equipment (tablet, computer, or TV)
metadata.training_required: Practitioners must complete certified VIG training

contraindications: Families unwilling to engage with video feedback
Severe caregiver psychiatric illness limiting ability to participate
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe, supportive, and non-intrusive. May initially cause self-consciousness around being filmed.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate evidence, with growing research base
clinical_metadata.research_support: Several studies and program evaluations suggest that VIG improves parental sensitivity, child outcomes, and family wellbeing, particularly in early years and child protection contexts.

sections.text: VIG works by highlighting and reinforcing positive moments of interaction between caregivers and children. Watching and reflecting on successful communication builds confidence, self-awareness, and attunement. This helps parents shift focus from problems to strengths, improving relationships and communication patterns.

sections.preparation: Obtain consent and explain process of video recording and feedback. Establish goals for improving interactions.
procedure: Record short clips of parent-child (or caregiver-child) interaction during play or everyday activities.
Practitioner selects positive, attuned interaction moments.
Feedback session: watch video clips together, focusing on strengths and successful communication.
Collaboratively reflect on strategies to build on positive moments.
Repeat over several sessions to reinforce progress.

sections.pre_session: Check-in and set focus for recording.
sections.treatment_phase: Video recording of interactions, followed by guided feedback and reflection.
sections.post_session: Parents practice skills between sessions and apply strategies in daily life.

absolute: Caregivers with severe untreated mental illness
relative: High parental resistance to reflective approaches

ideal_candidates: Parents seeking to improve bonding with their child
screening_required: Parental consent and willingness to engage
Initial assessment of relationship and communication concerns

practitioner: Certified VIG practitioners with specialized training

studies: Kennedy, H., Landor, M., & Todd, L. (2011). Video Interaction Guidance as a method to promote secure attachment.
Fukkink, R. G. (2008). Video feedback in education and training: Meta-analysis.
sections.limitations: Research base is smaller compared to more established therapies. Effectiveness can depend on parental engagement and practitioner skill.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Low to moderate, depending on session number
sections.insurance_coverage: Varies; may be included under family therapy or parenting interventions
sections.cost_effectiveness: Considered cost-effective for preventing long-term family difficulties

sections.children: Particularly beneficial for infants and young children to support attachment.
sections.adolescents: Can be adapted to improve communication with teenagers.
sections.cultural: Adaptable across cultural contexts, but requires sensitivity in video use.

items: VIG emphasizes empowerment and strengths rather than deficit correction.
Requires strong therapeutic alliance to ensure parents feel supported rather than judged.
Flexible and can be adapted for professional supervision and training in caregiving professions.
